unit_learning_outcomes.description: Explain the principles of evolutionary biology and their role in human health and disease
Utlise basic bioinformatic skills, including handling of genetic sequence data
Interpret and demonstrate understanding of the primary scientific literature
Explain the importance of new techniques in human genetics for understanding human disease
Understand genetics and its basis in human disease
Solve problems in human genetics using appropriate analytical methods and a variety of up to date resources

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: 1 hour prep time for each lecture

enrolment_rules.description: 130cp at 1000 level or above including BIOL2110 or BIOL206(P)

assessments.description: Ongoing problem sets for tutorials throughout the semester
A written literature review of the methodology of a genomic technique
Formal examination covering all content of unit

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 1, Infrequent attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances
Session 1, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances, Other
data.subject_search_title: BIOL3120 - Human Genetics and Evolutionary Medicine
data.description: This unit deals with the molecular, cellular and population basis of the genetics of human beings in relation to disease and evolutionary medicine. Topics include: genetics, genomics, disease gene discovery, evolutionary medicine and the social and ethical implications of studies in human genetics. Emphasis is placed upon the enormous impact which recent molecular advances have had upon the subject, as well as techniques of genetic analysis. Comparisons with the genetics of other vertebrates are made wherever appropriate.
data.search_title: BIOL3120 - Human Genetics and Evolutionary Medicine
